author: jwinfrey@cullmantimes.com(Jake Winfrey)
title: PREP FOOTBALL: Raiders sputter in 31-15 region loss to Locust Fork
text:
by Jake Winfrey 
GOOD HOPE — It was a tough day all around for Good Hope during Friday’s region matchup against Locust Fork. 
The Raiders secured just 148 total yards, surrendered more than 300 rushing to the Hornets and ultimately failed to take advantage of good field position and a whopping 23 penalties in an eventual 31-15 defeat inside James W. Shabel Stadium. 
With the loss, Good Hope dropped to 2-4 (1-3 Class 4A, Region 7), while Locust Fork improved to 3-3 (2-2) on the season. 
Coach Alan Scott didn’t take too long to diagnose what exactly went wrong for his team following the tilt. 
“We didn’t play well tonight, and they played excellent,” he lamented. “Give them credit, though. They came out and hit us in the mouth from the word, ‘Go.’ I’ve just got to do a better job of getting our guys ready.” 
The Hornets found the end zone on their opening possession on a fine 31-yard scamper by quarterback Chase Rice. 
They padded the cushion to 19-0 by halftime on a 37-yard scoring toss from Michael Reid to Dylan Hurst and a 5-yard jaunt by Chase Biles in a dominant second quarter that saw the visitors outgain the home team on the stat sheet 148-23 in total yardage. 
Meanwhile, the Raiders had the ball inside Locust Fork territory on four separate occasions in the first half — only to come away with nothing to show for it. 
Good Hope trailed 25-0 early in the fourth quarter before cashing in a nice drive with a 12-yard touchdown run by senior Jonathan Burnette. 
Although Locust Fork scored only four plays later, Scott’s squad came right back with a sublime 42-yard aerial strike from Riley Eisner to Matt Cofer — followed by a 2-point conversion rumble by Lee Whisenant — which cut the deficit to just two scores with more than 4 minutes left. 
Unfortunately, Locust Fork recovered the ensuing onside kick and was able to milk the clock dry with a few first downs for the victory. 
“Coming out of halftime, we wanted to dig in and get what we could,” Scott said. “We just couldn’t get anything going until late, but our guys played hard until the end. I appreciated that effort.” 
Eisner finished 6 of 12 through the air for 90 yards and a touchdown. The junior also hauled in an interception on defense. 
Matthew Dixon, Whisenant and Burnette combined for 82 rushing yards on 19 carries, Matt Hancock tossed in three receptions for 30 yards and Dakota Burney had his nose in several tackles defensively. 
Rice ended his game with 150 total yards and two scores, while Biles and sophomore tailback Drew Rogers combined for most of the ground damage for the Hornets. 
They’ll host DAR next week in what could prove to be a pivotal tilt with postseason implications. 
For Good Hope, the chance for a playoff bid is still on the table. 
It’ll just have to traverse an extremely difficult three-bout stretch that includes 4A No. 6 Priceville, DAR and North Jackson. 
Think Scott and his kids are done fighting? 
Not a chance. 
“Absolutely not,” he said. “We’re going to try to win every game that we play.”
